ParentCompanyName: Central Valley Water Reclamation Facility Board

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Central Valley Water Reclamation Facility is a wastewater treatment plant located at about the middle of the Salt Lake Valley.  This plant was put on line 1988 to replace five old, existing, out dated plants that were having trouble meeting their permits.  This plant was mandated by the EPA to improve the wastewater treatment in the Salt Lake Valley.  Since the Central Valley Water Reclamation (CVWRF) was organized in 1980, it has been faced with meeting stringent standards with facilities that were old and near the end of their operative life.  Chlorination of the plant effluents is part of the treatment.  In the old plants, this was accomplished with liquid chlorine brought on plant site in ton containers. With the advent of the new regional plant, the chlorine is brought on plant site in 90 ton rail tank cars.  However, the most that is ever on plant site is about 60 tons.In, addition, new regulations required the addition of sulfur dioxide to eliminatethe chlorine residual being discharged to the receiving waters.  This requirement added another hazardous chemical to be handled.  Sulfur dioxide is brought on plant site in tank truck quantities and transferred to a rail tank car stored permanently on site.  Since the start of the plant, CVWRF has not had a reportable incident with either chlorine or sulfur dioxide.  In spite of the fact that much more hazardous material is stored on plant site, the use of rail cars and bulk quantities have made the process more safe than ever before.

          CVWRF's policy regarding the safety of plant personnel and surrounding population is that we intend to comply with all safety rules and agencies to make this a safe plant and good neighbor.  CVWRF has a team that is trained in handling both chlorine and sulfur dioxide and is ready to deal with whatever emergency may arise.  Safety equipment to cap leaks at the tank car.  Regular exercises are held to rehearse the procedures necessary to deal with emergencies.

Since we have had no severe accident, there is no planned change to the Safety Program.  There is, however, an on going safety training and monitoring of procedures and situations throughout the plant.  Whenever changes are felt to be appropriate, changes are made and if necessary SOP's written or updated.
